query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 ‘Al Padre, al Figlio, a lo Spirito Santo’, 2 cominciò, ‘gloria!’, tutto ’l paradiso, 3 sì che m’inebrïava il dolce canto.
query.result:
**English:**
1 "To the Father, to the Son, to the Holy Spirit," 2 began, "glory!", all of paradise, 3 so that the sweet song intoxicated me.
**Old English:**
1 "Þam Fæder, and þam Suna, and þam Halgan Gaste," 2 ongonn, "lof sy!" eall ðæt Leohte, 3 swa ðæt me ðæs sanges wynsumade.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Ciò ch’io vedeva mi sembiava un riso 5 de l’universo; per che mia ebbrezza 6 intrava per l’udire e per lo viso.
query.result:
**English:**
4 What I saw seemed to me a smile 5 of the universe; so that my drunkenness 6 entered through hearing and through sight.
**Old English:**
4 Þæt ic ðær geseah ðuhte me anres 5 ðæs eallweoruldes; forðæm min eagena wyn 6 eode in ðurh ðæt gehlystan and ðurh ðæt gesihð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Oh gioia! oh ineffabile allegrezza! 8 oh vita intègra d’amore e di pace! 9 oh sanza brama sicura ricchezza!
10 Dinanzi a li occhi miei le quattro face 11 stavano accese, e quella che pria venne 12 incominciò a farsi più vivace,
13 e tal ne la sembianza sua divenne, 14 qual diverrebbe Iove, s’elli e Marte 15 fossero augelli e cambiassersi penne.
query.result:
**English:**
7 Oh joy! Oh ineffable gladness! 8 Oh life wholly filled with love and peace! 9 Oh secure wealth without desire!
10 Before my eyes the four torches 11 stood alight, and the one that came first 12 began to grow brighter,
13 and in its appearance it became 14 like what Jove would become if he and Mars 15 were birds and exchanged their feathers.
**Old English:**
7 O gefean! O unasecgendlic myrgð! 8 O lif eall gehealden on lufe and sibbe! 9 O unbedæled geweald butan gewilnunge!
10 Beforan minum eagum ða feower leoman 11 stodon bærnende, and se ðe ær com 12 ongan weorðan beorhtra,
13 and swylc on his hiwe wearð, 14 swylce Iupiter wurde, gif he and Mars 15 wæron fugelas and gebigdon him fidera.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 La provedenza, che quivi comparte 17 vice e officio, nel beato coro 18 silenzio posto avea da ogne parte,
19 quand’ ïo udi’: «Se io mi trascoloro, 20 non ti maravigliar, ché, dicend’ io, 21 vedrai trascolorar tutti costoro.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Providence, which here distributes 17 office and duty, had imposed 18 silence on every side in the blessed choir,
19 when I heard: "If I change color, 20 do not be amazed, for, as I speak, 21 you will see all these others change color."
**Old English:**
16 Þæt foresceawung, ðe ðær dælð 17 gesceaft and weorc, on ðam beorhtan cwearme 18 hæfde eallum ðone sweg onweg adræfd,
19 ða ic ðus clypode: "Gif ic awende min hiw, 20 ne wundrige ðe, forðam ðe, ðonne ic ðis secge, 21 ðu gesyhst ealle ðas oðre awendan heora hiw."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Quelli ch’usurpa in terra il luogo mio, 23 il luogo mio, il luogo mio, che vaca 24 ne la presenza del Figliuol di Dio,
25 fatt’ ha del cimitero mio cloaca 26 del sangue e de la puzza; onde ’l perverso 27 che cadde di qua sù, là giù si placa».
query.result:
**English:**
22 Those who usurp my place on earth, 23 my place, my place, which is empty 24 in the presence of the Son of God,
25 have made my cemetery a sewer 26 of blood and stench; therefore the evil one 27 who fell from up here is appeased down there.
**Old English:**
22 Þa þe on eorðan minum stede brucað, 23 minum stede, minum stede, se þe westeð 24 beforan ðæs Godes Bearnes gesihðe,
25 hafað geworht of minum byrgene stincendne seð, 26 of blode and of stence; þurh ðone bið geblissod 27 se awyrgda þe of heonon feoll, þær niðer.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Di quel color che per lo sole avverso 29 nube dipigne da sera e da mane, 30 vid’ ïo allora tutto ’l ciel cosperso.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Of that color which, because of the sun opposite, 29 a cloud paints in the evening and in the morning, 30 I saw then all the sky covered.
**Old English:**
28 ðæs hiwes þe ðurh ðone sunnan onswed 29 wolcen hiowæð æfen and morgen, 30 ða geseah ic ða eall ðone rodor oferroden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E come donna onesta che permane 32 di sé sicura, e per l’altrui fallanza, 33 pur ascoltando, timida si fane,
34 così Beatrice trasmutò sembianza; 35 e tale eclissi credo che ’n ciel fue 36 quando patì la supprema possanza.
query.result:
**English:**
31 And like a virtuous woman who remains 32 self-assured, and because of another's failing, 33 even just listening, she becomes timid,
34 so Beatrice changed countenance; 35 and I believe there was such an eclipse in heaven 36 when the supreme power suffered.
**Old English:**
31 And swa swa clæne wif ðe ðurhwunað 32 selfre hyre trywe, and ðurh oðres mannes unriht, 33 ðeah ðe heo ðæt gehыре, ðonne forhted heo,
34 swa Beatrice hire bleo forwand; 35 and ic wene ðæt swylc gedreorig wæs on heofonum 36 ða ða ða mæste miht ðrowode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Poi procedetter le parole sue 38 con voce tanto da sé trasmutata, 39 che la sembianza non si mutò piùe:
40 «Non fu la sposa di Cristo allevata 41 del sangue mio, di Lin, di quel di Cleto, 42 per essere ad acquisto d’oro usata;
43 ma per acquisto d’esto viver lieto 44 e Sisto e Pïo e Calisto e Urbano 45 sparser lo sangue dopo molto fleto.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Then his words proceeded 38 with a voice so changed from itself 39 that his appearance did not change more:
40 "The bride of Christ was not brought up 41 by my blood, by Linus, by Cletus, 42 to be used for the acquisition of gold;
43 but for the acquisition of this joyful life 44 Sixtus and Pius and Callistus and Urban 45 shed their blood after much weeping.
**Old English:**
37 Þa forðferde his word swa 38 mid stefne swa swiðe awended fram him, 39 ðæt his hiw ne awende na mare:
40 "Ne wæs Cristes bryd gecoren 41 of minum blode and of Lines and of Cletes, 42 to bionne mid golde gegierwed;
43 ac to bionne mid ðisum life gefean 44 Sixtus and Pius and Callistus and Urbanus 45 agoto[n] heora blod æfter miclum gewepe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 In vesta di pastor lupi rapaci 56 si veggion di qua sù per tutti i paschi: 57 o difesa di Dio, perché pur giaci?
58 Del sangue nostro Caorsini e Guaschi 59 s’apparecchian di bere: o buon principio, 60 a che vil fine convien che tu caschi!
61 Ma l’alta provedenza, che con Scipio 62 difese a Roma la gloria del mondo, 63 soccorrà tosto, sì com’ io concipio;
64 e tu, figliuol, che per lo mortal pondo 65 ancor giù tornerai, apri la bocca, 66 e non asconder quel ch’io non ascondo».
query.result:
**English:**
55 In the guise of shepherds, ravenous wolves 56 are seen from up here in all the pastures: 57 O defense of God, why do you lie still?
58 Cahorsins and Gascons are preparing 59 to drink our blood: O good beginning, 60 to what a vile end you must fall!
61 But the high providence, which with Scipio 62 defended Rome, the glory of the world, 63 will come to our aid soon, as I conceive;
64 and you, my son, who for the mortal burden 65 will return down below, open your mouth, 66 and do not hide what I do not hide."
**Old English:**
55 On hierdes gegyrelan reaflac wulfas 56 sint gesewene her and her on eallum foldum: 57 ea, Godes werod, hwi ligge ge swilce?
58 Ures blodes Caursine and Gascoine 59 georne drincen: ea, god ongin, 60 to hwilcum ende scealt ðu gewurðan!
61 Ac se hehsta wisdom, se ðe mid Scipione 62 bewerode Rome weorðmynt ðises middangeardes, 63 sona gefylst, swa ic on mode geþence;
64 and ðu, min sunu, ðe ðurh ðone deadlican byrðen 65 eft ongean cymst, ontŷn ðinne muð, 66 and ne forhele ðæt ðe ic ne forhele."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Sì come di vapor gelati fiocca 68 in giuso l’aere nostro, quando ’l corno 69 de la capra del ciel col sol si tocca,
70 in sù vid’ io così l’etera addorno 71 farsi e fioccar di vapor trïunfanti 72 che fatto avien con noi quivi soggiorno.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Just as flakes of frozen vapor 68 fall through our air, when the horn 69 of the goat of heaven touches the sun,
70 so I saw the sky above 71 adorned and raining down flakes of triumphant vapors 72 that had made their dwelling here with us.
**Old English:**
67 Swa swa ðæs wætres dropan feallað 68 of heofonum niðer, ðonne hægles scûr 69 of ðæs heofones horn geond ðone lyft gæð,
70 swa ic ðær geseah ða lyft afylled 71 mid sigefolca sawlum, ða ðær samod 72 wunedon mid ðam Wealdende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Lo viso mio seguiva i suoi sembianti, 74 e seguì fin che ’l mezzo, per lo molto, 75 li tolse il trapassar del più avanti.
query.result:
**English:**
73 My sight followed his appearance, 74 and followed until the middle, because of the multitude, 75 took away from them the passing beyond.
**Old English:**
73 Min gesihð folgode his hiwum, 74 and folgode oð ðæt ðæt middel, ðurh ða menigu, 75 him benam ðone forðgang ðæs furðor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Onde la donna, che mi vide assolto 77 de l’attendere in sù, mi disse: «Adima 78 il viso e guarda come tu se’ vòlto».
query.result:
**English:**
76 Whereupon the lady, who saw me freed 77 from waiting above, said to me: "Raise 78 your face and see how you are turned."
**Old English:**
76 Þa ða wæpnedwif, ðe ðær wæs wunigende, 77 ða heo ðone cniht geseah ðær ufan cuman, 78 ða cwæð heo to ðam cnihte: "Nu ðu scealt faran."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 E più mi fora discoverto il sito 86 di questa aiuola; ma ’l sol procedea 87 sotto i mie’ piedi un segno e più partito.
query.result:
**English:**
85 And the site of this little plot would have been more revealed to me, 86 but the sun was moving 87 beneath my feet, and the sign was departing more and more.
**Old English:**
85 And ðeos eard wæs me swiðor geswutelod, 86 ðæs wongstealles; ac se sunu drohte 87 under minum fotum and se tacen wæs todæled.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 La mente innamorata, che donnea 89 con la mia donna sempre, di ridure 90 ad essa li occhi più che mai ardea;
91 e se natura o arte fé pasture 92 da pigliare occhi, per aver la mente, 93 in carne umana o ne le sue pitture,
94 tutte adunate, parrebber nïente 95 ver’ lo piacer divin che mi refulse, 96 quando mi volsi al suo viso ridente.
query.result:
**English:**
88 My enamored mind, which always yearns 89 to bring my lady before me, 90 burned with a greater desire than ever to see her;
91 and if nature or art ever created 92 something pleasing to the eye, in order to capture the mind, 93 whether in human flesh or in paintings,
94 all of these things combined would seem as nothing 95 compared to the divine pleasure that shone upon me 96 when I turned to her smiling face.
**Old English:**
88 Min geþōht se geleaffulla, se þe geornor 89 symle mid mīnum wife wæs, tō weccanne 90 tō hire ðā ēagan swīðor þonne ǣfre;
91 and gif gecynd oððe cræft geworhte 92 tō gesyhðe tō nimanne, tō habbanne ðone mōd, 93 on menniscum flæsce oððe on his gewritum,
94 ealle gesamnode, hī woldon þyncan nānwuht 95 wið ðone wuldorlican wyllan þe mē gewāt, 96 þā ic mē gewende tō hire hlihhande neb.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 E la virtù che lo sguardo m’indulse, 98 del bel nido di Leda mi divelse, 99 e nel ciel velocissimo m’impulse.
query.result:
**English:**
97 And the power that indulged my gaze, 98 tore me from the fair nest of Leda, 99 and thrust me into the swiftest heaven.
**Old English:**
97 And ðæt mægen ðe ðone gesihð me sealde, 98 of ðæs fægran Leda neste me astrehte, 99 and on ðone swiftestan heofon me sende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Le parti sue vivissime ed eccelse 101 sì uniforme son, ch’i’ non so dire 102 qual Bëatrice per loco mi scelse.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Her most lively and exalted parts 101 are so uniform that I cannot say 102 which Beatrice chose for me as a place.
**Old English:**
100 Hire ða mæstan and ða mæran dæl 101 synd swa efenlice, ðæt ic ne cann secgan 102 hwæðer Beatrijs me ðær to setle geceas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Ma ella, che vedëa ’l mio disire, 104 incominciò, ridendo tanto lieta, 105 che Dio parea nel suo volto gioire:
106 «La natura del mondo, che quïeta 107 il mezzo e tutto l’altro intorno move, 108 quinci comincia come da sua meta;
109 e questo cielo non ha altro dove 110 che la mente divina, in che s’accende 111 l’amor che ’l volge e la virtù ch’ei piove.
query.result:
**English:**
103 But she, who saw my desire, 104 began, laughing so joyously, 105 that God seemed to rejoice in her face:
106 "The nature of the world, which quiets 107 the center and moves all the rest around, 108 begins here as from its goal;
109 and this heaven has no other where 110 than the divine mind, in which is kindled 111 the love that turns it and the power that it rains down.
**Old English:**
103 Ac heo ðe ðæt geseah ðone minan willan, 104 ða ongan heo ða hlihhan swa bliðe, 105 ðæt ðæs Godes andwlita ðær on wæs blide:
106 "Ðæs middangeardes gecynd ðe ðisne middangeard 107 on ðære midde gestildeð and ða oðre ðing ealle ymb ðone 108 onginneð her swa swa of his ende;
109 and ðeos heofon ne hæfð nan oðer hwær 110 buton ðone Godes gast, on ðam ðe bið onæled 111 se lufe ðe hine wyleð and ða mihte ðe he of him ræneð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Luce e amor d’un cerchio lui comprende, 113 sì come questo li altri; e quel precinto 114 colui che ’l cinge solamente intende.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Light and love encompass him in a circle, 113 just as this one encompasses the others; and that circle 114 only he who is encircled by it understands.
**Old English:**
112 Leoht and lufu him onhring hafað, 113 swa ðeos ðas oðre; and ðæt gewealc 114 ðone ðe hit ymbclyppeð ana ðæt andgit.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Oh cupidigia che i mortali affonde 122 sì sotto te, che nessuno ha podere 123 di trarre li occhi fuor de le tue onde!
124 Ben fiorisce ne li uomini il volere; 125 ma la pioggia continüa converte 126 in bozzacchioni le sosine vere.
query.result:
**English:**
121 O greed, that plunges mortals 122 so deep beneath you that none has the power 123 to lift their eyes out of your waves!
124 The desire flourishes in men, 125 but the constant rain turns 126 the true blossoms into worthless husks.
**Old English:**
121 Ea, gifru, ðe ða deadlican sencoð 122 swa ðe under ðe, ðæt nan ne mæg 123 ahebban his eagan ufor ðinra yða!
124 Wel blóweð on ðam men ðæs willan blóstma; 125 ac ðæs regnes scúr hrade forcierreð 126 ða soðan blóstman to bosme gelice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Fede e innocenza son reperte 128 solo ne’ parvoletti; poi ciascuna 129 pria fugge che le guance sian coperte.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Faith and innocence are found only 128 in little children; afterwards everyone 129 flees them before their cheeks are covered.
**Old English:**
127 Treowe and unsynnigne sind afundene 128 ana ðæm lytlingum anum; ðonne ælc 129 fleoð ða ær ðonne ða wlite bewrigen sien.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Così si fa la pelle bianca nera 137 nel primo aspetto de la bella figlia 138 di quel ch’apporta mane e lascia sera.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Thus the white skin becomes black 137 in the first aspect of the beautiful daughter 138 of him who brings morning and leaves evening.
**Old English:**
136 Swa bið ðæt hwitte wæter blac 137 æt ðæs fægeran bearnæs frumsceawe 138 ðæs ðe dæg bringð and niht læteð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Tu, perché non ti facci maraviglia, 140 pensa che ’n terra non è chi governi; 141 onde sì svïa l’umana famiglia.
query.result:
**English:**
139 You, so that you may not marvel at this, 140 consider that there is no one who governs on earth; 141 hence the human family goes so astray.
**Old English:**
139 ðu, ðæt ðu ðe ne wundrige, 140 ðenceð ðæt on eorðan nis ðe ðe stihte; 141 ðanon si swiðe mancyn gewiteð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Ma prima che gennaio tutto si sverni 143 per la centesma ch’è là giù negletta, 144 raggeran sì questi cerchi superni,
145 che la fortuna che tanto s’aspetta, 146 le poppe volgerà u’ son le prore, 147 sì che la classe correrà diretta;
148 e vero frutto verrà dopo ’l fiore».
query.result:
**English:**
142 But before January is all covered in snow, 143 because of the hundredth [canto] that is neglected down there, 144 these supernal circles will so revolve,
145 that Fortune, who is so eagerly awaited, 146 will turn the sterns where the prows are, 147 so that the fleet will run straight;
148 and true fruit will come after the flower.
**Old English:**
142 Ac ærðan ðe geolores eall gewurðe 143 ðurh ða hundrede ðe ðær niðan licgeð, 144 swa hrade willað ðas heofoncundan hweowol,
145 ðæt ðæt gesælde ðe man swa longe abæd, 146 ðæt ða steortas willað gewendan ðær ða stefnas nu syndon, 147 swa ðæt ðæt scip ryhte ræseð;
148 and soðfæst wæstm cymeð æfter ðam blostman.
